awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding the Synergistic Effect of Graphene Plasmonics and Nanoscale Spatial Confinement on Solar-Driven Water Phase Change
awd_abstract_narration:
Water desalination and wastewater treatment rely on the consumption of significant amounts of energy.  For distributed water treatment systems, the cost can be ten times higher than that of the centralized plants. The ability to use renewable energy such as solar energy to replace completely, or in part, the energy needed for water treatment may lead to substantial impacts on the sustainability of the global energy and water supply.  Efficient solar-thermal energy conversion for vapor generation is an important green technology that could reduce the energy demands of water desalination and wastewater treatment.  However, the low vapor evaporation rate remains a challenge for many practical applications. Graphene plasmonics, which refers to the collective electron oscillation in graphene flakes when excited by light, is believed to contribute to the enhanced solar-to-thermal conversion efficiency of graphene nanopetal structures. In this research project, computer modeling and experiments will be combined to understand the synergistic effects of graphene plasmonics and spatial confinement on thermodynamic properties of water and the solar-driven water evaporation rate. The knowledge gained from this study will assist in developing new graphene plasmonic materials for solar thermal evaporation applications. The project will also include significant educational activities, such as outreach programs for local K-12 students and teachers and undergraduate research programs with open-ended design projects.

The goal of this research project is to understand how the plasmon resonance-induced local electric field due to extreme light confinement along the unique nanopetal edges either aligns or dis-aligns water molecular dipoles confined between the vertically freestanding graphene flakes in a porous structure.  The research project integrates full electromagnetic wave calculations, molecular simulations, and experimental validation.  Some of the specific objectives include understanding the fundamental mechanisms governing the influence of graphene plasmonics-induced thermodynamic property change of nano-confined water on vapor evaporation rate.  A combination of electromagnetic wave calculations and molecular simulations will be used to model this system.  Additionally, the researchers will validate the modeling results through experiments on solar-driven water phase change mediated by anomalous near-infrared plasmons in uniquely synthesized porous graphene nanopetal structures. This project is expected to reveal new mechanisms of graphene plasmon resonance-mediated water phase transition, which may contribute to improving solar-thermal energy conversion technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Final outcome report

Understanding the Synergistic Effect of Graphene Plasmonics and Nanoscale Spatial Confinement on Solar-Driven Water Phase Change

(CBET-1937949)

 

Efficiently utilizing solar-thermal energy conversion to enable liquid-to-vapor phase transition has attracted tremendous attention as a green and renewable technology to address pressing global water scarcity. The ability to use renewable energy such as solar energy to replace completely, or in part, the energy needed for water treatment may lead to revolutionary impact on a sustainable future of the global energy and water supply, and significantly strengthen the energy-water nexus. The project has generated new fundamental knowledge in understanding light-matter interaction during solar energy harvesting and thermodynamics of water during phase transition. New processing routes have also been designed to fabricate advanced solar evaporators with ultra-high and stable evaporation rates (> 3 kg m−2 h−1 at 1 sun) for practical seawater (even for hypersaline water with 20 wt.% NaCl) desalination applications. The results of our research have been substantial, leading to the publication of 18 peer-reviewed journal papers. Additionally, our findings and methodologies have been shared with the wider scientific community through communications with peers at the Materials Research Society (MRS) international conference. These outcomes of the project garnered significant interest and recognition in the field.

 

The broader impact of the NSF project stretches beyond the fundamental research. The results of this project may contribute to improving the resilience of the energy-water nexus. The mechanisms of light-matter interaction and water phase change understood may pave the road for further studies in this field, which may eventually lead to a wide range of advanced environmental and energy applications. For example, the knowledge offers insights into developing graphene metamaterials to address pressing global issues (e.g., water scarcity), which accelerates broader applications of graphene metamaterials to many other forms of solar energy harvesting such as photocatalysis, solar cells and nanofluid transport. The proposed research also generated systematic, insightful techniques of controlling the physical and chemical properties of graphene materials, which could benefit the fabrication and development of ultra-lightweight materials with excellent thermal insulation and outstanding mechanical properties. The knowledge of thermal management of solar-thermal vapor generation systems obtained from this NSF project can also benefit the development of other high-performance, safe energy storage and conversion systems such as batteries and electronic devices.

 

Moreover, a significant focus of our project was on the educational and training aspects, where we actively engaged with students from the University of Texas at Dallas (UTD). Multiple (> 8) undergraduate students at UTD participated in this project through Independent Study Projects and Undergraduate Research courses or as volunteers. The project generated a significant impact on the PI’s teaching and educational experiences in his two core undergraduate-level classes at UTD. Specifically, the modules on solar-enabled water desalination involving thermodynamics, thermal management, nanomaterials, and solar energy harvesting serve as a valuable enhancement to PI’s courses. Our educational goal is to cultivate the interests of the young generation in STEM fields, particularly the traditionally underrepresented minorities and groups, in the areas of thermal transport, energy and materials, help them to acquire relevant knowledge and skills, and train the workforce of the future.
